title: Pollux (mountain)
text:
Pollux () is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> in the <a href="Pennine%20Alps">Pennine Alps</a> on the border between <a href="Valais">Valais</a>, <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> and the <a href="Aosta%20Valley">Aosta Valley</a> in <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. It is the lower of a pair of twin peaks (), the other being <a href="Castor%20%28mountain%29">Castor</a>, named after the <a href="Gemini%20twins">Gemini twins</a> of <a href="Roman%20mythology">Roman mythology</a>. Pollux' peak is at an elevation of . It is separated from Castor by a pass at , named "Passo di Verra" in Italian, "Col de Verra" in French and "Zwillingsjoch" in German.
The first ascent was by Jules Jacot from Geneva with guides Josef-Marie Perren and Peter Taugwalder (father) on August 1 (the Swiss national day) 1864. Their route was via the Schwarztor, a pass first crossed by John Ball and Gabriel Zumtaugwald in 1845. The impressive north ridge was first climbed by Captain <a href="John%20Percy%20Farrar">John Percy Farrar</a> (a future President of the <a href="Alpine%20Club%20%28UK%29">Alpine Club</a>) and Wylie Lloyd with guide Josef Pollinger of <a href="St.%20Niklaus">St. Niklaus</a> in the canton Valais on 18 August 1893.
Ascents are usually made from the <a href="Refuge%20Ottorino%20Mezzalama">Refuge Ottorino Mezzalama</a> (3,036 m), the Monte Rosa hut (2,795 m); if traversing the peaks via Pollux's north ridge, PD+, the <a href="Refuge%20Quintino%20Sella%20au%20F%C3%A9lik">Refuge Quintino Sella au Félik</a> (3,585 m), and the Rossi-Volante bivouac hut (3,850 m).
The first winter and ski ascent of Pollux was by Dr Alfred von Martin and Karl Planck on 7 March 1913.
